title: Alzheimer’s Risk Among Women
content: There is a greater Alzheimer’s risk among women. Women living longer has been proposed as the reason for greater Alzheimer’s risk, but that this does not explain all of the difference. Perimenopause is a “brain disease”. During perimenopause there are metabolic shifts in the brain that can predispose to acceleration of Alzheimer’s pathology. This is underappreciated and can be countered with appropriate use of estrogen replacement. The disruption of sleep, the brain fog, problems with processing speed and attention, are all symptoms of perimenopause. Perimenopause transition is a huge unrealized risk factor for progression to dementia in an Alzheimer’s susceptible woman.

title: Factors Contributing to Alzheimer’s Risk in Women
content: Hysterectomy can be a contributing factor in the progression of Alzheimer's disease. Widowhood is a astronomically important risk factor for cognitive decline and dementia. Women with an enlarged waist circumference have a 39% increase in dementia risk. In men, muscle mass is a more important predictor than body fat, but the reason for this difference between men and women is not yet known.

title: Current Study on Alzheimer’s Risk
content: A study is currently being conducted involving comprehensive brain imaging in men and women between the ages of 40-65 to determine the reason for the difference in Alzheimer’s risk between men and women.
